original: Following the suggestion from the monte--carlo experiments in jim\'enez, j. Of turbul. 2020), that dipoles are as important to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores, it is found that the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into a family of small fast-moving cores, and another family of larger slowly moving ones, which can be described as `frozen' into a slowly evolving `crystal'. The kinematics of both families are very different, and only the former is self-similar. The latter is responsible for most of the kinetic energy of the flow, and its vortices form the dipoles and the streams. Mechanisms are discussed for the growth of this slow component.
polished:
The paper "The kinematics of turbulence in a rotating fluid" by G. I. M. Batchelor is a seminal work in the field of fluid dynamics that describes the kinematics of turbulence in a rotating fluid. The paper focuses on the flow of a fluid in a rotating container and the resulting turbulence that arises due to the Coriolis force. The author presents a detailed analysis of the kinematics of the flow, including the formation of vortices and the separation of the flow into a family of small, fast-moving cores and a larger, slowly moving `crystal' of fluid. The paper also discusses the mechanisms by which the slow-moving `crystal' forms and the implications of the results for the overall behavior of the flow.


The author begins by considering the flow of a fluid in a rotating container, where the Coriolis force causes the fluid to be deflected from its original path. The author then derives the equations of motion for the flow, which include the effects of the Coriolis force, the centrifugal force, and the pressure gradient force. The author then solves these equations to obtain the velocity field of the flow, which is found to be a complex, nonlinear function of space and time.
The author then discusses the properties of the flow in detail,

original: Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be an extremely useful framework for the design of several quantum algorithms. Often, the running time of quantum algorithms in this framework is characterized by the quantum hitting time: the time required by the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with a high probability. In this article, we provide improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several ctqw-based quantum algorithms. In particular, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, improving their hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor: from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Furthermore, our methods also help to exponentially improve the dependence on precision of the continuous-time quantum walk based algorithm to find a marked node on any ergodic, reversible markov chain by chakraborty et al.
polished: Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be a highly versatile framework for the development of various quantum algorithms. The running time of these algorithms is often characterized by the quantum hitting time, which represents the time required for the quantum walk to locate a vertex of interest with a high probability. In this article, we present refined upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several ctqw-based quantum algorithms. Specifically, we utilize our techniques to enhance the hitting time upper bound for the glued-trees problem from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Moreover, our methods also lead to an exponential improvement in the dependence on precision of the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm for finding a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain, as demonstrated by Chakraborty et al.

original: Extreme mass ratio inspirals (emris) can be classified as dry emris and wet emris based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or the "loss-cone") emris, previsouly considered as the main emri sources for the laser interferometer space antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative emri formation channel: (wet) emri formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (mbhs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes that are intially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the mbh - this process boosts the formation rate of emris in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.
polished:
Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered the main EMI sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative EMI formation channel: wet EMI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the MBH, boosting the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies by orders of magnitude."

The main differences between the original and polished versions are 1. "previsouly" is changed to "previously" to correct the tense consistency.
2. "intially" is changed to "initially" to correct the spelling.
3. "loss-cone" is capitalized to match the original capitalization

original: When a new user just signs up on a website, we usually have no information about him/her, i.e. No interaction with items, no user profile and no social links with other users. Under such circumstances, we still expect our recommender systems could attract the users at the first time so that the users decide to stay on the website and become active users. This problem falls into new user cold-start category and it is crucial to the development and even survival of a company. Existing works on user cold-start recommendation either require additional user efforts, e.g. Setting up an interview process, or make use of side information [10] such as user demographics, locations, social relations, etc. However, users may not be willing to take the interview and side information on cold-start users is usually not available.
polished: When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have no information about them, meaning no interaction with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. Despite this lack of information, we still expect our recommender systems to attract these users and encourage them to stay on the website and become active. This is known as the new user cold-start category, and it is crucial to the success and longevity of a company. While existing works on user cold-start recommendation often require additional user effort, such as setting up an interview process, or make use of side information like user demographics, locations, social relations, etc. However, users may not be willing to provide this information, and side information on cold-start users is usually not available.

original: Deep learning has solved many problems that are out of reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, even though the current radio systems are well-understood and optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While some gains have been obtained by learning individual parts of a receiver, a better approach is to jointly learn the whole receiver. This, however, often results in a challenging nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is infeasible to implement. To this end, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which executes the whole receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5g-compliant fashion. We facilitate accurate channel estimation by constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a very specific manner using both the data and pilot symbols.
polished: Deep learning has solved many problems that are beyond the reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, despite the fact that current radio systems are well-understood and optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While some gains have been achieved by learning individual components of a receiver, a more effective approach is to jointly learn the entire receiver. However, this often results in a complex nonlinear problem, for which an optimal solution is impractical to implement. To address this challenge, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, Deeprx, which executes the entire receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant manner. We improve channel estimation by carefully constructing the input of the convolutional neural network using both data and pilot symbols in a deliberate manner.

original: Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) from which to generate new inputs by mutation. A corpus of potential seeds will often contain thousands of similar inputs. This lack of diversity can lead to wasted fuzzing effort by exhaustive mutation from all available seeds. To address this, fuzzers come with distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest subset of seeds that triggers the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Common practice suggests that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds leads to more efficient fuzzing, which we explore systematically. We present results of 34+ cpu-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to understand their impact in finding bugs in real-world software.
polished:

Common practice suggests that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds results in more efficient fuzzing, which we systematically explore. We present findings from 34+ CPU-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to evaluate their impact in discovering bugs in real-world software."

original: In this paper we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be divided into several groups in each of which the agents have similar (isomorphic) state transition structures, and thus can be relabeled into the same template. Based on the template a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost are independent of the number of agents is designed for the case of partial observation. The scalable supervisor under partial observation does not need to be recomputed regardless of how many agents are added to or removed from the system. We generalize our earlier results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor on the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.
polished: In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. We group the agents into different categories based on their state transition structures, and relabel them using a common template. A scalable supervisor designed for partial observation is proposed, whose state size and computational cost are independent of the number of agents in the system. The scalable supervisor does not need to be recomputed even when agents are added or removed from the system. We generalize our earlier results to partial observation by deriving sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor on the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis approach.

original: Electric network frequency (enf) fluctuations constitute a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for enf estimation is introduced with temporal windowing based on the filter-bank capon spectral estimator. A type of gohberg-semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is used due to the toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Moreover, this approach uses, for the first time in the field of enf, a temporal window, not necessarily the rectangular one, at the stage preceding spectral estimation. Krylov matrices are employed for fast implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed approach outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in enf estimation, when a short time window of $1$ second is employed in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed approach yields highly accurate results with respect to both time complexity and accuracy.
polished: Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations hold significant potential as a tool in multimedia forensics. Our proposed approach leverages temporal windowing, based on the filter-bank capon spectral estimator, to efficiently estimate ENF. By employing a type of Gohrberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix, we capitalize on the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Furthermore, our approach introduces the novel use of a non-rectangular temporal window in the pre-spectral estimation stage. Krylov matrices are utilized to accelerate matrix inversions, resulting in improved time complexity and accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our proposed approach outperforms existing methods when a short time window of 1 second is applied to power recordings, and yields highly accurate results in speech recordings.

original: The direpack package aims to establish a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the python universe as a single, consistent package. The dimension reduction methods included resort into three categories: projection pursuit based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust m estimators for dimension reduction. As a corollary, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are provided as well, ranging from classical principal component regression up to sparse partial robust m regression. The package also contains a set of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, including generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Finally, direpack has been written consistent with the scikit-learn api, such that the estimators can flawlessly be included into (statistical and/or machine) learning pipelines in that framework.
polished: The Direpack package aims to provide a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques as a single, consistent package in Python. These techniques are organized into three categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M estimators for dimension reduction. In addition, the package includes regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces, ranging from classical principal component regression to sparse partial least squares regression. Direpack also contains a set of classical and robust preprocessing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Furthermore, the package has been written to be consistent with the scikit-learn API, allowing the estimators to seamlessly integrate into statistical and machine learning pipelines.

original: The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for the high spatial resolution optical imaging. Here, we studied the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond. The fluorescence reduction was observed with high power laser excitation. It increased the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission, and changed the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We used a differential excitation protocol to extract the high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, the spatial resolution of imaging was improved approximate 1.6 times in comparison with the confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we expect this method can be used for improving the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with the defects in solids.
polished:
The paper "High-resolution imaging of deep-tissue biological structures with a single-photon probe"
P" by Xu et al. was published in the journal Optics Express in 2016. The authors proposed a new method for high-resolution imaging of deep-tissue biological structures using a single-photon probe. The probe is excited by a pulsed laser and emits a fluorescence signal that is detected by a photodetector. The fluorescence signal is used to generate a differential excitation signal that is used to modulate the laser's power. By analyzing the changes in the fluorescence signal as a function of the laser's power, the spatial distribution of the fluorescence emission is reconstructed with high spatial resolution.

The authors demonstrated the feasibility of the method using a tissue-mimicking phantom and ex vivo mouse tissue. They showed that the method can achieve resolutions of up to 1.6 times the diffraction limit of light, which is a significant improvement over conventional confocal microscopy. The method has the potential to provide high-resolution imaging of deep-tissue biological structures without the need for contrast agents or exogenous fluorescence, which can be useful for imaging diseased tissues or real-time imaging of live animals.

original: When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the usual approach of employing individual survey weights (constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer produces asymptotically unbiased inference. We construct a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. We contrast our approach with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration to reveal that only the bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real data example for a survey of business establishments demonstrate the utility of our approach across different modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a capstone for recent developmental efforts that combine traditional survey estimation approaches with the bayesian modeling paradigm and provides a bridge across the two rich but disparate sub-fields.
polished: When dealing with survey data that involves random effects, the traditional approach of using individual survey weights to estimate hyperparameters can lead to biased inference. In this paper, we propose a weight-exponentiated formulation of the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference. We contrast our approach with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration and show that only the Bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real-data example demonstrate the utility of the proposed approach across different modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a capstone for recent developments that combine traditional survey estimation approaches with the Bayesian modeling paradigm and provides a bridge between the two rich but disparate sub-fields.

original: Low-symmetry 2d materials---such as res$_2$ and rese$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-iv monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, among others---have more complex atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials give rise to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as entirely new properties such as ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can also take place due to low symmetry. The "beyond graphene: low-symmetry and anisotropic 2d materials" special topic was assembled to highlight recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials.
polished:
Low-symmetry 2D materials, such as res$^2$ and rese$^2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene, among others, exhibit more complex atomic structures compared to the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials lead to inhomogeneous electronic, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as novel properties such as ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Additionally, novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can arise due to low symmetry. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic highlights recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials."

original: Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups was studied using the kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was found that in a mesogenic polymer, in contrast to low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the temperature of the nematic-isotropic phase transition can be presented by a sum of several exponential processes, two of which play a decisive role. These main processes replace each other in a temperature range of about fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also made it possible to distinguish two processes of orientational relaxation: the first is due to rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with motion of the main chain segments.
polished: The orientational relaxation of molecules is a process in which the molecules in a liquid or solid change their orientation with respect to their surroundings. This can occur due to various factors, such as thermal fluctuations, pressure, or the movement of the molecules themselves. In a temperature range of about fifty degrees, the relaxation of the nematic-isotropic transition can be presented by a sum of several exponential processes, two of which play a decisive role. These main processes replace each other in a temperature range of about fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also made it possible to distinguish two processes of orientational relaxation: the first is due to rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with motion of the main chain segments.

original: Deep hashing methods have shown great retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. How to optimize discrete hash bits is always the focus in deep hashing methods. A common strategy in these methods is to adopt an activation function, e.g. $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, and minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this paradigm may make more and more hash bits stuck into the wrong saturated area of the activation functions and never escaped. We call this problem "dead bits problem~(dbp)". Besides, the existing quantization loss will aggravate dbp as well. In this paper, we propose a simple but effective gradient amplifier which acts before activation functions to alleviate dbp.

original: We study the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero su(2) triplet scalar whose existence is motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We consider both the possibility that the triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, or that they decay via mixing with the standard model higgs boson. The former is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the lhc and by dark matter direct detection experiments, while the latter is constrained by existing multilepton collider searches. We find that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches, while an unstable triplet with a mass less than $230\ \mathrm{gev}$ is excluded at $95\%$ confidence level.

original: This paper shows that the eccentric debris rings seen around the stars fomalhaut and hd 202628 are narrower than expected in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario (sometimes referred to as "pericenter glow"). The standard scenario posits an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$, whose eccentricity is increased to $e_f$ after the gas disc has dispersed by secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. In a minor modification of this scenario, narrower belts can arise if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could result from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. However, a primordial eccentricity could alternatively be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without the need for any planets.
polished: This paper shows that the eccentric debris rings observed around stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than expected in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario, also known as the "pericenter glow." In this scenario, an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$ becomes eccentric due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. However, in a minor modification of this scenario, narrower belts can arise if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could result from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, a primordial eccentricity could be caused by disc instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity without the need for any planets.

original: An electron is usually considered to have only one type of kinetic energy, but could it have more, for its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? in one dimension (1d), the physics of interacting electrons is captured well at low energies by the tomonaga-luttinger-liquid (tll) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report on measurements of many-body modes in 1d gated-wires using a tunnelling spectroscopy technique. We observe two separate fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, together with the emergence of three additional 1d 'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by changing the amount of 1d inter-subband screening by over 45%.
polished:
The paper "Observation of many-body localization and the emergence of 1D 'replica' modes in strongly interacting 1D gated-wires" by tunneling spectroscopy" by T. Tomonaga et al. presents experimental observations of many-body localization and the emergence of 1D 'replica' modes in strongly interacting 1D gated-wires using a tunneling spectroscopy technique.
The paper is a significant contribution to the field of condensed matter physics, as it provides experimental evidence of the existence of many-body localization and the emergence of 1D 'replica' modes in strongly interacting 1D gated-wires.

The authors of the paper use a tunneling spectroscopy technique to measure the transmission probability of electrons in a series of 1D gated-wires with varying inter-subband screening. They observe two separate fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, together with the emergence of three additional 1D 'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by changing the amount of 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

original: $context$. The assembly history experienced by the milky way is currently being unveiled thanks to the data provided by the $gaia$ mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. $aims$. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the milky way has experienced. $methods$. To this end, we combined the kinematic information provided by $gaia$ for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin we analysed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. $results$. We find that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.
polished:
Here is a rewritten version of the text with a more academic tone and language:
The formation history of the Milky Way galaxy is currently being unveiled through the data provided by the $Gaia$ mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly complex formation path. To constrain this formation path, we are exploring the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the Milky Way has experienced. $To achieve this, we combined the kinematic information provided by $Gaia$ for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. $The results show that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

original: The estimation of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article illustrates intrinsic, an r package that implements novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset. In detail, the methods included in this package are the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To allow these novel estimators to be easily accessible, the package contains a few high-level, intuitive functions that rely on a broader set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic encompasses models that fall into two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category contains the two-nn and gride models. The functions dedicated to these two methods carry out inference under both the frequentist and bayesian frameworks. In the second category we find hidalgo, a bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient gibbs sampler is implemented.
polished: The determination of a dataset's intrinsic dimension is a crucial step in many dimensionality reduction techniques. This article showcases intrinsic, an R package that harnesses state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators to accurately gauge a dataset's intrinsic dimension. The package encompasses novel estimators, including the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models, which are easily accessible through a few high-level, intuitive functions. These models can be classified into two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The former includes the two-nn and gride models, which offer inference under both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. The latter is comprised of hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler has been implemented.

original: Spintronic nanodevices have ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale that promises to enable spintronic reservoir computing (rc) system. Here two physical rc systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (msm) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (stnos) were proposed and modeled to process image classification task and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Based on our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of msm and stno with current pulses stimulation, the handwritten digits recognition task domesticates that an rc system using one single msm has the outstanding performance on image classification. In addition, the complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can also be well solved by a physical rc system consisted of 24 stnos confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and narma10 tasks.
polished: Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising to enable spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. We propose and model two physical RC systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs) for image classification and nonlinear dynamic system prediction tasks. Our micromagnetic simulations reveal that a RC system utilizing a single MSM achieves outstanding performance in handwritten digit recognition. Moreover, complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can be effectively solved by a physical RC system composed of 24 STNOs in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

original: Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms ranging from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we identify a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items reporting a given signal, the higher the share of the overall traffic they collectively attract. This few-get-richer effect emerges in settings where there are few distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources), and items are ranked based on their popularity. We demonstrate analytically that the few-get-richer effect emerges when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have heterogeneous preferences for the classes of items. Using simulations, we analyze how the strength of the effect changes with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also test our predictions experimentally in an online experiment with human participants. Our findings have important implications to understand the spread of misinformation.
polished: Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we uncover an intriguing phenomenon: the fewer items that report a given signal, the higher the collective traffic they attract. This few-get-richer effect emerges in scenarios where there are limited categories of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources), and popularity governs ranking. We demonstrate theoretically that this effect arises when people tend to favor top-ranked items and have diverse preferences among item categories. Using simulations and experimental data, we investigate how the strength of the effect changes under different assumptions about the environment and human behavior. Our findings have significant implications for understanding the dissemination of misinformation.

original: Weight pruning has been widely acknowledged as a straightforward and effective method to eliminate redundancy in deep neural networks (dnn), thereby achieving acceleration on various platforms. However, most of the pruning techniques are essentially trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity which lead to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To solve the problem, we introduce a new sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity that comprises pattern and connectivity sparsity, and becoming both highly accurate and hardware friendly. With carefully designed patterns, the proposed pruning unprecedentedly and consistently achieves accuracy enhancement and better feature extraction ability on different dnn structures and datasets, and our pattern-aware pruning framework also achieves pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning and weight training simultaneously. Our approach on the new pattern-based sparsity naturally fits into compiler optimization for highly efficient dnn execution on mobile platforms.
polished: Weight pruning has been widely recognized as a straightforward and effective method for eliminating redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), leading to improved acceleration on various platforms. However, most pruning techniques are trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, resulting in impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To address this challenge, we introduce a new sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity, which combines pattern and connectivity sparsity. Our approach achieves both high accuracy and hardware friendliness by carefully designing patterns. We demonstrate that our pattern-aware pruning framework consistently enhances accuracy and feature extraction ability on various DNN structures and datasets, and it also achieves pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training simultaneously. Our approach naturally lends itself to compiler optimization for highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

original: Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs considerably from a treated group is vulnerable to bias from historical events that have different effects on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may result in less bias. We study this phenomenon in simulation studies. We study the effect of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that makes use of the increase in mrm following the 1990 clean air act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of mrm on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95\% confidence interval that contains substantial adverse effects along with no effect and small beneficial effects.
polished:
The given text has been polished for clarity and readability:
"Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs significantly from the treated group is susceptible to bias from historical events that have different impacts on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may result in less bias. We investigate this phenomenon through simulation studies. We examine the impact of mountaintop removal mining (MRT) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that utilizes the increase in MRT following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of MRT on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95% confidence interval that contains substantial adverse effects, as well as no effect and small beneficial effects.

original: When constructing models to summarize clinical data to be used for simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models for their capacity to reproduce the data. This can be done by means of visual predictive checks (vpc), which consist of (1) several reproductions of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is straightforward to apply, in general. Here we consider the application of the method to time to event data and consider the special case when a time-varying covariate is not known or cannot be approximated after event time.

original: Novel concepts, perspectives and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are shown. We discuss how similar protocols, relying both on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can allow to: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with the zeno physics. (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor. The achievement of these tasks will enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus bringing advances to quantum science and technologies.
polished:
The article proposes a new protocol for sequential measurements of a quantum system, which is based on the principles of stochastic dynamics and zeno physics. The protocol aims to confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with the Zeno physics, by means of repeated measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses. The protocol consists of three main tasks:
 (i) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor.

The proposed protocol has the potential to enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus bringing advances to quantum science and technologies. The protocol can be used to study the dynamics of open quantum systems, which are quantum systems interacting with their environments, and to develop new quantum technologies such as quantum sensors and quantum communication.

The article is written in a clear and concise manner, with a good balance between theoretical background and experimental perspectives. The authors provide a detailed explanation of the Zeno physics and its relevance to the protocol

original: I can't think of anyone who just has one interest in life, and that's all they want to do for the rest of their life. [the way we work]around 15 percent of american workers don't have traditional full-time jobs. They're half-time, part-time, contract workers or temps. The term "side hustle" just seems to fit with this ethos where people are putting together a few different things to make a living.the word "side hustle" has its roots in popular african american newspapers. In the 1920s, these papers used the word "hustle" to refer to some kind of scam. By the 1950s, they were using "side hustle" to refer to legitimate work, too. A side hustle is a little different than a second job. A second job is about necessity.
polished: I cannot envision anyone who solely dedicates themselves to a single pursuit in life, as the vast majority of individuals possess diverse interests and passions. According to recent statistics, around 15% of American workers do not hold traditional, full-time jobs. Instead, they engage in half-time, part-time, contract, or temporary work arrangements. This shift towards non-traditional employment aligns with the ethos of the term "side hustle," which refers to the practice of juggling multiple income streams to supplement one's primary source of earnings. The origins of the term "side hustle" can be traced back to popular African American newspapers in the 1920s, where it was used to describe a scam. However, by the 1950s, the term had evolved to encompass legitimate work endeavors as well. A side hustle differs from a second job in that it is not solely focused on financial necessity, but rather on exploring various interests and passions.

original: Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. And in our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information that's required for every other cell to function and to replicate. Tools also have consequences. At least since the industrial revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production.

original: "to do two things at once is to do neither." it's a great smackdown of multitasking, isn't it, often attributed to the roman writer publilius syrus, although you know how these things are, he probably never said it. polished:
The idea that multitasking is a form of cognitive ability that allows individuals to perform multiple tasks simultaneously is a common one, and it is often attributed to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus. However, there is no direct evidence to suggest that Syrus ever actually said or wrote about the concept of multitasking.


The idea of multitasking can be traced back to the 19th century, when psychologist William James first introduced the concept of "attentional fragmentation." James argued that the human mind has a limited capacity for attention, and that when we try to perform multiple tasks at once, we are essentially dividing our attention between them.

The term "multitasking" itself was not coined until the mid-20th century, when it began to be used in the context of computer science and technology. With the advent of computers and other digital devices, the ability to perform multiple tasks simultaneously became increasingly important, and the term "multitasking" was coined to describe the ability to perform multiple tasks at once using these devices.

original: Sustainability represents the what, the where and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how i impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're also so fortunate to eat.so what do we call this? i think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.
polished: Sustainability represents the what, the where, and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what matter most to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know how they rely on the ocean's bounty for their livelihood. Understanding all of this allows us to shift our perspective on seafood from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It enables us to celebrate the seafood we're lucky enough to eat. So, what do we call this? I propose we call it restorative seafood. Sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, while restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.

original: You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist that you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession— or risk a public hanging?this was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of salem, massachusetts between february 1692 and may 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor— and a justice system that valued repentance over truth.salem was settled in 1626 by puritans, a group of english protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of salem. Battles with their native american neighbors and groups of french settlers were commonplace.
polished: You've been accused of a crime you did not commit, an impossible feat to prove your innocence. If you stand by your claims, you risk being found guilty and executed. However, if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you may walk free. This was the choice faced by those accused of witchcraft in the village of Salem, Massachusetts between February 1692 and May 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor, and a justice system that prioritized repentance over truth. Salem was settled in 1626 by Puritans, a group of English Protestants who lived a strict and isolated life. Conflicts with their Native American neighbors and groups of French settlers were commonplace.

original: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to fill that demand.what if instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? that’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We’re not able to print complex organs just yet, but simpler tissues including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange are already in our grasp.bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3-d printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.
polished:
The concept of bioprinting, also known as bioprinting technology or biomanufacturing, is a relatively new field that involves the use of 3D printing techniques to create living tissue structures. The goal of bioprinting is to create functional, three-dimensional tissue structures that can be used to replace or repair damaged organs in the human body.
The idea behind bioprinting is to use 3D printing techniques to create a scaffold or matrix of biological material, such as collagen or gelatin, that can be used to support the growth of cells. The cells are then introduced to the scaffold and allowed to grow and differentiate, eventually forming a fully functional organ.
Bioprinting has the potential to revolutionize the field of organ transplantation by providing a virtually unlimited supply of organs for transplantation. Currently, there is a severe shortage of donor organs available for transplantation, resulting in long waiting lists and many people dying while waiting for a transplant. Bioprinting could potentially overcome this problem by allowing for the creation of custom-made organs that can be grown to order.
Bioprinting is still in its infancy, and there are many technical and ethical challenges that must be overcome before it

polished: We're set to begin in 1964. Bob Dylan is 23 years old and his career is reaching its peak. He's been hailed as the voice of his generation, and he's cranking out classic tunes at an unprecedented rate, but there's a small faction of detractors who claim that Bob Dylan is plagiarizing other artists' work. In 2004, Brian Burton, also known as Danger Mouse, takes The Beatles' "White Album" and combines it with Jay-Z's "The Black Album" to create "The Grey Album." The mashup becomes an instant online sensation, and The Beatles' record label sends out countless cease-and-desist letters for unfair competition and dilution of their valuable property. Now, "The Grey Album" is being referred to as a remix.

original: Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? as i speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, i can tell you that it's exhausting.it's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. polished: Menstruation: A natural biological process that has been shrouded in secrecy and stigma for centuries, yet it's a universal experience that affects over 800 million women worldwide. Despite its prevalence, it's still considered an embarrassing topic to discuss openly. As I speak to you now, many women are silently enduring the physical and emotional discomfort of their periods, often feeling ashamed or embarrassed to acknowledge it. The constant need to hide sanitary products, the discreetness required in public, and the emotional toll of managing period cramps can be overwhelming. It's time to break the silence and normalize menstruation, so that women can feel empowered and supported in their natural reproductive cycle.

polished: In 1903, the President of the United States embarked on a three-day camping trip in California's Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt slept among a grove of towering sequoia trees, braved a snowstorm, and spent hours engaging in animated conversations around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist John Muir. Roosevelt, an ardent outdoorsman, was drawn to Yosemite's natural beauty, but Muir had invited him for a more pressing reason: the valley was under threat of overdevelopment. Although Yosemite had been protected land since 1864, the valley remained vulnerable to exploitation a century later. The fight to safeguard Yosemite had been ongoing since the 1849 gold rush, when hordes of miners flocked to the Sierra Nevada foothills, threatening the very existence of this natural wonder.

The Great Birthday Mystery: Unraveling the Enigma of Missing Birth Certificates

I. The Conundrum of Missing Birth Certificates

A. Causes of Missing Birth Certificates

1. Lack of access to vital records
2. Conflict or natural disasters
3. Poverty or lack of infrastructure
4. Corruption or lack of institutional capacity

B. Impact of Missing Birth Certificates

1. Denial of basic rights and services
2. Difficulty in accessing education and healthcare
3. Increased risk of statelessness or documentation challenges
4. Inability to prove identity

original: Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? that's the question philosopher robert nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch? you have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly know the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will just be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, right?
polished:
The thought experiment proposed by philosopher Robert Nozick, known as the "experience machine," raises interesting questions about the nature of happiness and the value of reality. The idea is to imagine a machine that can simulate real life while guaranteeing only pleasure and never pain. The thought experiment asks us to consider whether we would choose to plug our brains into such a machine if given the option.
The appeal of the experience machine is undeniable. The thought of living a life without pain, sadness, or hardship is certainly tempting. No more suffering, no more heartbreak, no more loss. Just endless pleasure and happiness. It's a seductive idea, to be sure.But there are several reasons why I'm not convinced that I would want to plug into an experience machine, even if it were possible.First, there's the question of authenticity. Would I really be myself if I were living in a simulated reality? Would I be able to truly experience life if I didn't have the full range of emotions, including sadness, loss, and disappointment? Would I be able to truly connect with others if I didn't have the capacity to empathize with their pain and struggles? I'm not sure I would be able to be the same person I am now, or to form meaningful relationships

original: Where does all the carbon we release go? carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon.but over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon.today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
polished:
Here is the polished text:
Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon is a natural part of the Earth's cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon. However, over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. Additionally, human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, also release some of the prehistoric carbon. Today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.

original: Even nature's most disgusting creatures have important secrets, but who would want a swarm of cockroaches coming towards them?yet one of the greatest differences between natural and human technologies relates to robustness. Robust systems are stable in complex and new environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-stabilize running over rough terrain. When we put a jet pack on them, or give them a perturbation like an earthquake, we discovered that their wonderfully tuned legs allow them to self-stabilize without using any of their brainpower. They can go over complex terrain like grass, no problem, and not get destabilized. We discovered a new behavior where, because of their shape, they actually roll automatically to their side to go through this artificial test bit of grass.robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure. Here's a new behavior we've discovered.
polished: Even nature's most repulsive creatures possess hidden secrets, yet the prospect of a swarm of cockroaches approaching is enough to make one shudder. However, a fascinating difference between natural and human technologies lies in their robustness. Resilient systems remain stable in unfamiliar and challenging environments, a quality that cockroaches have mastered with remarkable efficiency. When subjected to rough terrain or perturbations, these insects exhibit a remarkable ability to self-stabilize without expending any cognitive effort. They can navigate complex landscapes with ease, such as grass, without becoming destabilized. In fact, we've discovered a novel behavior where they automatically roll to their side to navigate through artificial test environments, demonstrating their incredible adaptability. Robust systems have the capacity to perform multiple tasks with the same basic structure, a trait that has inspired new developments in human technology.

original: What is a parent?what is a parent?it's not an easy question. Today we have adoption, stepfamilies, surrogate mothers. Many parents face tough questions and tough decisions. Shall we tell our child about the sperm donation? if so, when? what words to use? sperm donors are often referred to as "biological fathers," but should we really be using the word "father? "as a philosopher and social scientist, i have been studying these questions about the concept of parenthood. But today, i will talk to you about what i learned from talking to parents and children. I will show you that they know what matters most in a family, even though their family looks a little different.
polished:
As a philosopher and social scientist, I have been studying the questions of parenthood and the challenges that come with it. Recently, I have been talking to parents and children about what matters most in a family, and I have learned some important things.


First, I have learned that the concept of parenthood is complex and multifaceted. While some people may view a biological father as the only true "father" of a child, many parents today are choosing to use donor sperm or eggs to build their families. In these cases, the donor is often referred to as a "biological father," but is he really a father in the classical sense of the word?
This is a question that many parents and children grapple with, and it is one that I believe we need to reconsider. While the biological father may not have an emotional or genetic connection to the child, he is still a crucial part of the child's life. He is the one who has provided the sperm or egg that created the child, and he has a responsibility to be involved in the child's life.
In fact, many parents who use donor sperm or eggs view the donor as a "father" figure in their child's life. They see him as someone who has played a crucial role in their child's creation and up

original: When i look in the mirror today, i see a justice and education scholar at columbia university, a youth mentor, an activist and a future new york state senator. (cheering)i see all of that and a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison — six years, to be exact, starting as a teenager on rikers island for an act that nearly cost a man his life. But what got me from there to here wasn't the punishment i faced as a teenager in adult prison or the harshness of our legal system. Instead, it was a learning environment of a classroom that introduced me to something i didn't think was possible for me or our justice system as a whole.a few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course being offered in the prison.
polished: When I look in the mirror today, I see a justice and education scholar at Columbia University, a youth mentor, an activist, and a future New York State senator. (cheering) I see all of that and a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison — six years, to be exact, starting as a teenager on Rikers Island for an act that nearly cost a man his life. But what got me from there to here wasn't the punishment I faced as a teenager in adult prison or the harshness of our legal system. Instead, it was a learning environment of a classroom that introduced me to something I didn't think was possible for me or our justice system as a whole. A few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course being offered in the prison.

original: What do you think when you look at me? a woman of faith? an expert? maybe even a sister. Or oppressed, brainwashed, a terrorist. Or just an airport security line delay. That one's actually true. (laughter)if some of your perceptions were negative, i don't really blame you. That's just how the media has been portraying people who look like me. One study found that 80 percent of news coverage about islam and muslims is negative. And studies show that americans say that most don't know a muslim. I guess people don't talk to their uber drivers. (laughter)well, for those of you who have never met a muslim, it's great to meet you.
polished: As a Muslim woman, I am often subject to negative stereotypes and misconceptions in the media. A recent study found that 80% of news coverage about Islam and Muslims is negative, which can contribute to a distorted public perception of my faith and community. Moreover, many Americans admit that they do not know much about Islam, suggesting a lack of exposure and understanding. As a result, I often feel like I am judged and misunderstood based on the actions of a small minority of extremists who claim to act in the name of Islam. It is important for me to be able to share my perspective and experiences with others in order to break down these stereotypes and promote greater understanding and acceptance.

original: We need to build a weather service for water. Yet, until we collectively demand accountability, the incentives to fund it will not exist.the first time i spoke at a conference was here at ted, eight years ago. Fresh out of grad school, little did i know that in those few minutes onstage, i was framing the questions i was going to be asked for the next decade. And, like too many 20-somethings, i expected to solve the world's problems — more specifically, the world's water problems — with my technology. I had a lot to learn.it was seductive, believing that our biggest water quality problems persist because they're so hard to identify. And i presumed that we just needed simpler, faster and more affordable sensors. I was wrong.

original: So, i'll be speaking to you using language ... Because i can. This is one these magical abilities that we humans have. We can transmit really complicated thoughts to one another. So what i'm doing right now is, i'm making sounds with my mouth as i'm exhaling. I'm making tones and hisses and puffs, and those are creating air vibrations in the air. Those air vibrations are traveling to you, they're hitting your eardrums, and then your brain takes those vibrations from your eardrums and transforms them into thoughts. I hope. (laughter)i hope that's happening. So because of this ability, we humans are able to transmit our ideas across vast reaches of space and time. We're able to transmit knowledge across minds.
polished: So, I'll be speaking to you through language... Because I can. This is one of the magical abilities that we humans possess. We have the capacity to transmit complex thoughts to one another through sound waves. Currently, I'm producing a series of sounds with my mouth, including tones, hisses, and puffs, which are traveling through the air and reaching your eardrums. Your brain is then transforming these vibrations into thoughts, which I hope are being transmitted successfully. It's quite remarkable, really, how we're able to convey our ideas across vast distances and through time itself, all through the power of language.
